For those who want the spoken word transcript:

The following are true stories.
May 26th 2003 Aron Ralston was hiking, a boulder fell on his right hand. He waited four days, then amputated his arm with a pocket knife.
On New Year‚Äôs Eve, a woman was bungee jumping in Zimbabwe. The cord broke, she then fell into a river and had to swim back to land in crocodile infested waters with a broken collarbone.
Claire Champlin was smashed in the face by a five pound watermelon being propelled by a slingshot.
Matthew Brobst was hit by a javelin.
David Striegl was punched in the mouth. By a kangaroo.
The most amazing part about these stories is when asked about the experience they all smiled, shrugged, and said ‚ÄúI guess things could have been worse.‚Äù
So go ahead.
Tell me that you‚Äôre having a bad day.
Tell me about the traffic. Tell me about your boss. Tell me about the job you‚Äôve been trying to quit for the past four years. Tell me the morning is just a town house burning to the ground and the snooze button is a fire extinguisher. Tell me the alarm clock stole the keys to your smile, drove it into 7:00 AM, and the crash totaled your happiness.
Tell me! Tell me!
Tell me, how blessed are we to have tragedies so small it can fit on the tips of our tongues?
You see, when Evan lost his legs he was speechless. When my cousin was assaulted, she didn‚Äôt speak for forty eight hours. When my uncle was murdered, we had to send out a search party to find my father‚Äôs voice.
Most people have no idea that tragedy and silence have the exact same address.
When your day is a museum of disappointments hanging from events that were outside of your control, when you find yourself flailing in an ocean of ‚ÄúWhy is this happening to me?‚Äù, when it feels like your guardian angel put in his two week notice two months ago and just decided not to tell you, when it feels like God is just a babysitter that‚Äôs always on the phone, when you get punched in the esophagus by a fistful of life, remember that every year two million people die of dehydration so it doesn‚Äôt matter if the glass is half full or half empty, there‚Äôs water in the cup.
Drink it, and stop complaining.
Muscle is created by repeatedly lifting things that have been designed to weigh us down. So when your shoulders feel heavy, stand up straight and lift your chin ‚Äì call it exercise. When the world crumbles around you, you have to look at the wreckage and then build a new one out of the pieces that are still here.
Remember, you are still here.
The human heart beats approximately four thousand times per hour.
Each pulse, each throb, each palpitation is a trophy engraved with the words ‚ÄúYou are still alive‚Äù.
You are still alive.
Act like it.

item.content:encoded:
Instead of asking first world Americans what poverty is... let's ask those who truly experience it. (Here are some responses, country name in CAPS)

"For a poor person everything is terrible‚Äîillness, humiliation, shame. We are cripples; we are afraid of everything; we depend on everyone. No one needs us. We are like garbage that everyone wants to get rid of."
‚Äî MOLDOVA

"During the past two years we have not celebrated any holidays with others. We cannot afford to invite anyone to our house and we feel uncomfortable visiting others without bringing a present. The lack of contact leaves one depressed, creates a constant feeling of unhappiness, and a sense of low self-esteem."
‚Äî LATVIA

"When one is poor, she has no say in public, she feels inferior. She has no food, so there is famine in her house; no clothing, and no progress in her family."
‚Äî UGANDA

"[The poor have] a feeling of powerlessness and an inability to make themselves heard."
‚Äî CAMEROON

"Your hunger is never satisfied, your thirst is never quenched; you can never sleep until you are no longer tired."
‚Äî SENEGAL

"What determines poverty or well-being? The indigenous people's destiny is to be poor."
‚Äî ECUADOR

The poor define poverty as more than lack of material possessions.
It is conditions more psychological and social then what we think: shame, inferiority, powerlessness, humiliation, fear, hopelessness, depression, social isolation, voicelessness, personal worthlessness, and social despair

We in the US tend to emphasize poverty as a lack of material things.
Analogy: Going to the doctor to treat an illness

  1. Doctor can misdiagnose the illness
  2. Doctor can merely try to reduce the symptoms (Mucinex)

If poverty is... -> Solution

Lack of knowledge -> education
Oppression by the powerful -> social justice
The personal sins of the poor -> evangelism and discipleship of the poor
Lack of material resources -> give $$$

Most of the time, simply giving money will do more harm than good because it doesn't get to the root cause of poverty.

Poverty alleviation efforts should be multifaceted as well
Human beings are spiritual, social, psychological, and physical beings

Our basic predisposition toward poor communities (people, organizations, institutions, culture) should include the notion that they are part of the good world that Christ created and is sustaining.

We are NOT bringing Christ to poor communities for the very first time. He has been active in these communities since the creation of the world.
A significant part of working in these poorer communities involves discovering and appreciating what God has been doing there for a long time.

The effects of the fall are manifested in the economic, social, religious, and political systems that humans have created throughout history

"Poverty is the result of relationships that do not work, that are not just, that are not for life, that are not harmonious or enjoyable. Poverty is the absence of shalom in all its meanings"
-Myers

There is still inherent goodness as Christ "holds all things together" and to "sustain all things by his powerful word"

WHO ARE THE POOR?

Every human being is poor in the sense of not experiencing these four relationships in the way that God intended.
We are all suffering from a poverty of spiritual intimacy, community, and stewardship

Until we recognize and embrace our mutual brokenness, our work with low-income people is likely to do more harm than good.

A shame called "poverty of being" is a major part of the brokenness that low-income people experience in their relationship with themselves. They feel inferior to others. This paralyzes the poor from taking initiative and seizing opportunities to improve their situation. They don't see them as children of God, highly valued, and sought after by the King Himself.

The 1st World "God-Complex"

The economically rich, higher-income population also suffers from the poverty of being.
"God-complex": subtle and unconscious sense of superiority in which they believe that they have achieved their wealth through their own efforts and that they have been anointed to decide what is best for low-income people, whom they view as inferior to themselves

How do you know you have a ‚Äúgod-complex‚Äù?
Why do you really want to help the poor?
Does it feel good to help those with less? It‚Äôs common to unintentionally reduce poor people to objects to fulfill a need to accomplish something ‚Äúgood‚Äù or ‚Äúnoble‚Äù.

One of the biggest problems in many poverty-alleviation efforts is that their design and implementation exacerbates the poverty of being of the economically rich (their god-complexes) and the poverty of being of the economically poor (their feelings of inferiority and shame)

The way we act towards the economically poor often communicates that we are superior and they are inferior.
When this problem is ignored, the shame and inferiority in the economically poor increase AND "compassion fatigue" (decreased willingness to help, increased disdain for those that are being helped) begins to develop in those trying to help.

Equation
Material definition of poverty + God-complexes of materially non-poor + Feelings of inferiority of materially poor = Harm to both materially poor and non-poor

By showing low-income people through our words, actions, and most importantly our ears that they are people with unique gifts and abilities, we can be part of helping them to recover their sense of dignity, even as we recover from our sense of pride.

Health and Wealth Gospel

We in America have sufficient buffers in place to shield us from most economic shocks.
We don't really need to trust God's sovereignty just to get us through the day.
Health and wealth gospel teaches that God rewards increasing levels of faith with greater amounts of wealth.
This is COMPLETE BS

WE ARE ALL POOR AND BROKEN

That being said, the economically poor face a unique set of struggles:
Vulnerability, powerlessness, isolation, physical weakness, helplessness, anxiety, suffocation, desperation unparalleled in the lives of the rest of humanity.
Lack of freedom to be able to make meaningful choices to affect one's situation

I chose this stock photo (at the top of this post) not because it has a sad-looking baby, but because the most advanced objects in the photo are the jacket zipper and the clean cut 2x4 pieces of wood.

Surgery 1:
Repair the meniscus

-- Longer, more extensive rehab (3+ months)

Surgery 2:
Shave most of meniscus off
++ Faster recovery (2-4 weeks)
-- Risk of long-time problems with knee (arthritis)

I have no choice of the surgery option... (Oh the uncertainty)
Surgeon will try for Surgery 1, but if the repair doesn't hold, they will fall back to Surgery 2.

Potential Complications

  2. Infection post surgery
  3. Deep vein thrombosis

    Haven't we already been liberated from the prison that we lock ourselves in???
    Jesus doesn't have the key... HE IS THE üîë

item.content:encoded:
The Voice of Adventure

"Those who try to keep their lives will lose them. But those who give up their lives will save them."
Luke 17:33

There is a rawness and a wonder to life. Pursue it. Hunt for it. Sell out to get it. Don't listen to the whines of those who have settled for a second-rate life and want you to do the same so they won't feel guilty. Your goal is not to love long; it's to live.

Jesus says the options are clear. On one side there is the voice of safety. You can build a fire in the hearth, stay inside, and stay warm and dry and safe.

Or you can hear the voice of adventure - God's adventure. Instead of building a fire in your hearth, build a fire in your heart. Follow God's impulses. Adopt the child. Move overseas Teach the class. Change careers. Run for office. Make a difference.

Sure it isn't safe, but what is?

Guatemala

  1. I'm getting too comfortable with the tech life in Silicon Valley
    People who are comfortable don't need Jesus, that's called PRIDE.
    According to Bob Goff, we need to live on the edge of our comfort zones; Living right on the edge of the "YIKES"
    God is the only true comforter
  2. I have an opportunity to directly help those in Guatemala with my technology skills. Years of computer science and helping my friends and family with technology issues have finally paid off.
  3. The opportunity to lead a group of high schoolers the first week of my mission trip. I've never really thought of myself as a leader, but this is my chance to share some of the many lessons I have learned from failing and falling short.
  4. Willow Creek Church's 10 year partnership with a clinic in Guatemala.
  5. Spanish - the name of the blog, my phone language for the past 5 years, Spanish - only - in - the - living - room last year

Estoy listo. En serio, he estado preparando para esta oportunidad desde mi viaje a Costa Rica en 2013.

Why Now?

  1. I have a break before full-time work
  2. I am ready to carry out "La Misi√≥n"
  3. God's voice of adventure is calling me

Prayer Requests:

  1. Knee Injury - ability to move in Guatemala
  2. Diet - obtaining necessary food in Guatemala
  3. Trip Funding - opportunity to be in Guatemala
  4. Pride - ability to serve wholeheartedly in Guatemala

Updated on 19/02/18

T-5 hours until I leave for the airport...

HOW IN THE WORLD DID I GET HERE???

Just saw Riley Lachance hit a buzzer beater 3 for Vanderbilt Basketball to get the W vs MSS.
Got to see Zach Hamer, Damian, Djery
It was all good...

Then I decided to go play basketball...

Why do you do this to yourself...

Playing pickup basketball is never a good idea. And I was "trying" a little too hard.

  • SARA MELBY... Athletic trainer and superwoman. What an incredibly kind human. For responding to my text and advising me how to proceed. I don't know how I'll ever thank you.

item.content:encoded:
When the journey ahead seems bleak, don't forget to look behind you and see all you have survived already

If you are reading this... Either you've had your ACL repaired or will have your ACL repaired.
... Or you are one of my blessed friends with strong ACLs üí™

While there is definitely a long road ahead, I can assure you it is not a road less traveled. (Check out the official ACL Club)


For those on the rehab journey or about to embark on one...

Here are some of my PRO TIPS:

1. Do NOT compare your recovery timeline with that of others.

  • Teddy Roosevelt said that "Comparison is the thief of joy" and in this case it is also the thief of a healthy and stable recovery as well.
  • Yes, Adrian Peterson was running in 12 weeks and doing NFL level workouts in 5 months... but not all knees were created equally. Comparing my timeline with AP's does nothing...
  • I don't have his surgery, rehabilitation protocol, body composition, and 24/7 training staff.

2. Set rehab goals for yourself

  • Just because you aren't comparing to others doesn't mean you can't set goals for your rehabilitation
  • Tell yourself you are going to increase your ROM by X degrees this week
    • Do those leg raises without the brace
    • Walk a lap on the track
    • Single leg balance for the first time

3. Don't think of PAIN as a "bad" thing

  • Especially when you are cranking those heel slides out... remember how crucial ROM is in your life.
  • If you want full ROM again, just keep pulling

4. Redefine Your Definition of "Failure"

  • Failure is not lifting less weight than you used to lift when you were healthy
  • Failure is not running / walking / moving slower than you did pre-op
  • Let's be honest here, the only real failure is when you don't feel like doing your PT exercises or start dwelling on the things that your body currently cannot physically do.

5. Track Your Progress

  • Regardless if it's a diary, journal, blog, ... etc.
    What's important is that you are tracking your journey
  • This allows you to look back and reflect on the lessons you learned from rehab (I know you learned something)
  • This also allows you to see how far you've come (And boy is it amazing to see your strength double in nearly a week)

6. Change How You Measure Success

  • Stop measuring your "success" by what you can or can't do. (Somethings take longer to do than others)
  • Measure your success by effort, it's something you have 100% control over

7. Attitude is EVERYTHING

  • Studies have shown that a bad attitude affects more aspects of your live than just your rehab
  • Here are 3 sources that back me up
    1. TED Talk
    2. Can Negative Thinking Make You Sick?
    3. A Negative Attitude Affects Every Aspect Of Your Life
  • If you fully believe that today you will be at least 1% stronger than you were yesterday, what's stopping you from doing just that.

8. Learn Something New

  • What better time to start something new then when life throws you a curveball.
  • Suggestions:
    • Reading (non-academic, books you want to read... yes, those do exist)
    • Biking (This is the first high intensity cardio you will most likely be cleared to do)
    • Swimming (Once you are cleared to swim, it's no impact and great cardio)
    • Learn an instrument (As long as it doesn't require your recovering leg)
    • Learn a new language (You can learn almost any language online now, check out my favorite site, Duolingo)
  • Take time to enjoy something that you wouldn't have done if you didn't get hurt. Because that way, you will have learned / done something that without your injury you would have never learned.

9. Celebrate the Little Victories (Following up on #2.)

  • As it should be with anything in life, be sure to enjoy and celebrate the little achievements.

    Whether it be a few more degrees of ROM, or your first time walking without crutches / brace, or even your first pain-free lap around the track...
    A win is a win.

10. Practice Gratitude

  • I wholeheartedly believe gratitude is the only way to open the door to true joy and happiness
  • If you don't take my word for it, here are some TED Talks that reveal the truth and power behind gratitude

"Life changing gratitude does not fasten to a life unless nailed through with one very specific nail at a time"

"The whole of the life -- even the hard -- is made up of the minute parts, and if I miss the infinitesimals, I miss the whole. These are new language lessons, and I live them out. There is a way to live the big of giving thanks in all things. It is this: to give thanks in this one small thing. The moments will add up."
Ann Voskamp

(Posted on 04/19/2016; edited on 02/15/2017)

item.content:encoded:
6 a.m. and your hand can‚Äôt make it to the alarm clock before the voices in your head start telling you that it‚Äôs too early, too dark, and too cold to get out of bed.

Aching muscles lie still in rebellion, pretending not to hear your brain commanding them to move.

A legion of voices are shouting their unanimous permission for you to hit the snooze button and go back to dreamland

But you didn‚Äôt ask their opinion.

The voice you‚Äôve chosen to listen to is one of defiance. A voice that says there was a reason you set that alarm in the first place.

So sit up, put your feet on the floor, and don‚Äôt look back because we‚Äôve got work to do.

Welcome to The Grind.

For what is each day but a series of conflicts between the right way, and the easy way?

10,000 streams fan out like a river delta before you, each one promising the path of least resistance. Thing is‚Ä¶you‚Äôre headed upstream.

And when you make that choice, when you decide to turn your back on what‚Äôs comfortable, and safe, and what some would call ‚Äúcommon sense,‚Äù well that‚Äôs Day One. From there it only gets tougher.

So just make sure this is something you want, because the easy way out will always be there, ready to wash you away. All you have to do is pick up your feet‚Ä¶

But you aren‚Äôt going to, are you? With each step comes the decision to take another. You‚Äôre on your way now, but this is no time to dwell on how far you‚Äôve come. You‚Äôre in a fight against an opponent you can‚Äôt see, but oh, you can feel him on your heels, can‚Äôt ya? Feel him breathing down your neck.

You know what that is? That‚Äôs you. Your fears, your doubts and insecurities all lined up like a firing squad ready to shoot you out of the sky.

But don‚Äôt lose heart. While they are not easily defeated, they are far from invincible.

Remember, this is The Grind. The battle royale between you and your mind, your body, and the devil on your shoulder who‚Äôs telling you that, ‚ÄúThis is just a game. This is just a waste of time. Your opponents are stronger than you.‚Äù

Drown out the voice of uncertainty with the sound of your own heartbeat.

Burn away your self-doubt with a fire lit beneath you.

Remember what we are fighting for, and never forget that momentum is a cruel mistress. She can turn on a dime at the smallest mistake. She is ever searching for the weak place in your armor, that one tiny thing that you forgot to prepare for.

So as long as the devil is hiding in the details, the question remains: Is that all you got?‚Ä¶Are you sure?

And when the answer is ‚ÄúYes,‚Äù when you‚Äôve done all you can to prepare yourself for battle, then it‚Äôs time to go forth and boldly face your enemy. The enemy within.

Only now, you must take that fight into the open. Into hostile territory. You‚Äôre a lion in a field of lions, all hunting the same elusive prey with a desperate starvation that says, ‚ÄúVictory is the only thing that can keep you alive.‚Äù

So believe that voice that says: You can run a little faster. And you can throw a little harder. And that for you, the laws of physics are merely a suggestion.

Luck is the last dying wish of those who want to believe that winning can happen by accident. Sweat, on the other hand, is for those who know it‚Äôs a choice.

So decide now, because destiny waits for no man. And when your time comes, and a thousand different voices are trying to tell you, ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not ready for it,‚Äù listen instead to that lone voice of dissent. That one that says, ‚ÄúYou are ready. You are prepared.‚Äù

It‚Äôs all up to you now.

So rise and shine.

I started this post 2-months ago, but I couldn't quite think of what I could possibly add to the bold declaration above

Reflecting on my physical rehab journey, the 2016 NBA Finals (üò¢ Chef Curry), and my taste of work life, I have noticed that the "grind" only makes life more whole.

The joy, the fun, the laughs... and the human experienece itself all come from giving it all you got.
Whether it's that last lap in the pool, the final turn on the track, or even that final task you want to finish before leaving the office, just lock-in, anchor down, and do your best.

When you look back at the years and can only recall yourself giving only half of yourself, it's the worst feeling ever. Regret. Shame. Disappointment. Depression. Fear. One or more may fill your mind.

Instead, let those experiences remind you that you have so much more within yourself.

The only disability in life is a bad attitude.
